plans and procedures in place at this facility to respond to and safely mitigate any release or accident involving TDI products. Included in the emergency response plan are measures to be taken internally by QC West to control the release, if possible, and to make an initial notification to the Companys 24/7 Emergency Response Communication Network, SKYTANK. SKYTANK telecommunication operators will gather information and make necessary contact with emergency response services, state, local and federal agencies. 

QC West contracts with ERTS, a spill response management firm, who dispatches local contractors to conduct emergency response and remediation.  GrayMar Environmental Services, Inc. (GrayMar) is a local environmental service provider with offices in Gilbert, Arizona.  Based on proximity to the site, GrayMar could respond within 0-3 hours. QC West will work directly with GrayMar to discuss potential response services should a spill of TDI occur.  Any waste generated will be profiled for proper disposal. 

3.3   5-Year Accident History
QC West will ensure this 5-year accident history is updated, as needed, to include any accidental releases from this covered process that results in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

te (2,500 gallons per hour).  The release duration set at 5 minutes was based upon the timing it could take to shut down the transfer by using a manual shutoff valve. 

The MARPLOT program was used to obtain a population of 6 people within this 0.1 mile impact radius.  Both alternate release scenario analyses and maps are included in Appendix F.  

Section 3.0   Prevention and Emergency Response Programs

3.1   Accidental Release Prevention 
QC West is committed to protecting the health and safety of its employees, the surrounding community and the environment; therefore, it is Company policy to maintain compliance with 40 CFR 68.  To prevent and mitigate accidental releases of TDI products, the following precautionary measures are being implemented:

      Standard operating procedures (SOPs) for the transloading of TDI products from railcar to trailers. 
      Training program for employees involved in the transloading of TDI to ensure a high level of environmental, health, and safety regulatory compliance, and awareness of the elements of the RMP and release prevention.
      Routine audits and inspections to ensure compliance with established operating procedures, policies, and maintenance of transfer equipment.
      Documented inspection and maintenance programs for the transfer unit, railcars and trailers used for this covered operation.

The QC West facility utilizes SDSBinderWorks, an electronic SDS Management System, to maintain Safety Data Sheets (SDSs) for all products transloaded.  A copy of the terminals EAP is accessible by emergency responders on a 24 hour basis. In addition to local response agencies, the terminal is subject to inspection from the following agencies:
      Department of Transportation (DOT)
     	Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)
     	Arizona Department of Environmental Quality (ADEQ)
     	Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA)

3.2   Emergency Response Program
QC West has documented emergency response

as developed following EPA regulations and is considered to have an extremely low probability of occurrence since it is not likely an entire railcar to rupture, but could be the result of vandalism/theft, equipment malfunction, or poor tank integrity.  Additionally, this TDI product becomes set up (hardens) when exposed to air or moisture, therefore the chance of a toxic cloud forming is not likely.  If the railcar ruptures, it is more feasible for the 200,000 pounds of TDI product to spill onto the immediate ground and eventually harden. The product is not likely to infiltrate into the ground, and poses minimal risk to groundwater contamination. 

According to EPAs MARPLOT program, there are an estimated 166 people residing within the 0.2 mile radius who could be impacted by a release of TDI.  The worst-case scenario analysis and map are included in Appendix E.  

2.2 Alternative Release Scenario
QC West has evaluated several alternate release scenarios which are considered to have a higher-level probability of occurrence compared to the worst-case scenario; however, these also have a very low probability.  The two types of failure events evaluated for the alternate release scenario involves trailer rupture and hose rupture.  

The first alternate release scenario includes catastrophic failure, sudden and total failure of an entire trailer (45,000 pounds). Trailer rupture is not a likely scenario, but could result from vandalism/theft, equipment malfunction, or poor tank integrity. General tank integrity includes failures from normal wear or corrosion. The release duration was set to one minute.  As mentioned, this TDI product hardens when exposed to air or moisture, and therefore if the trailer ruptures, it is more likely for the 45,000 pounds of TDI product to spill onto the ground and harden instead of forming a toxic cloud.  

A second alternate release scenario evaluated includes a leak/rupture from the transfer hose, flowing approximately 425 pounds per minu

QC Wests corporate management is based at its Tampa, FL headquarters. Danielle Kruichak, Supervisor of Environmental Services, is responsible for the development, implementation, and integration of the risk management program elements, as well as, managing regulatory compliance for permits, programs and operations at all terminals.

Section 2.0   Offsite Consequence Analysis

Pursuant to 40 CFR 68.25, worst-case and alternate release scenarios were evaluated with regard to offsite consequences.  The software program RMP*CompTM developed by USEPA and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) was utilized to estimate endpoints for scenarios.  The offsite consequence analysis is required to be updated and reviewed at least once every 5 years (40 CFR §68.36). Reference Appendix D for the RMP Update Log.

2.1   Worst-Case Scenario Analysis
As required by 40 CFR 68 Subpart B, QC West has evaluated worst-case release scenarios for TDI. 40 CFR 68.22(a) defines the worst-case scenario to be the greatest distance in any direction to an endpoint resulting from an accidental release of regulated substances.  The worst-case release quantity is the greatest amount held in a single vessel. For this analysis, the rupture of a single railcar with a volume of 200,000 pounds was used.  In developing the release parameters of the worst-case scenario, QC West has not considered any passive mitigation measures, including building enclosures, dikes, containment walls, etc.  

Using the EPAs RMP*CompTM software program, it was determined that the distance to the toxic endpoint has the potential to result in a release with offsite consequences. The worst-case release scenario w

eless camera system that can be accessed remotely by facility and corporate personnel to ensure the safety and security of the property. 

1.2   Stationary Sources and Regulated Substances
QC West estimates transloading approximately 4,400,000 pounds (~450,000 gallons) per year of TDI from railcars into tank trailers.  Each railcar holds approximately 200,000 pounds of product and can be loaded into trailers each containing 45,000 pounds of product.  

According to the List of Regulated Substances under the Risk Management Program (40 CFR 68, Appendix A), TDI has a threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds. Since railcar storage exceeds this threshold, QC West is subject to RMP requirements.  QC West has developed the necessary policies, procedures and work practices for the safe handling of TDI.

QC West has determined this is a Program Level 2 process since public receptors are within the distance to endpoint for a worse-case-release, and handling of TDI is not covered under OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM) Program §29CFR 1910.119. This RMP includes the Prevention Program elements required in 68.48 through 68.60.

There is potential for there to be anywhere from one to two railcars onsite at any given time.  Each railcar could take approximately one to four weeks to unload. Railcars are never unloaded while connected to the locomotive, however, trailers being loaded with the TDI product are always hooked to the tractor and under active shipping papers.  Any railcar or trailer loaded with TDI will be inspected regularly and documented to ensure there are no spills, leaks, or incidents that could lead to a release. 

1.3   RMP Management 
QC West is required to develop a management system to oversee the implementation of the risk management program.  The Buckeye facility provides local management for terminal and maintenance shop operations including office dispatching services, transloading, and maintenance. Section 1.0   Executive Summary 

1.1   Introduction
QC West Coast Inc. (QC West) has prepared this Risk Management Plan (RMP), pursuant to 40 CFR 68, for the rail to tank truck transloading operations involving Toluene Di-isocyanate (TDI) at the Buckeye, AZ site.  QC West leases a 4.316 acres industrial property (Parcel #400-18-970A) located at 702 N 4th Street in Buckeye, AZ.  Reference Appendix A for a topographic map and Appendix B for a facility site map. 

QC West utilizes offices on the property to conduct bulk chemical tank truck dispatch operations, a shop for both tractor and trailer maintenance, and rail spurs for rail transload operations. Transloading operations conducted by QC West at the facility include transloading of both hazardous and non-hazardous materials directly from rail to tank trailers, which are then dispatched for customer delivery.

Facility Location Address:  702 N 4th Street, Buckeye, AZ 85326
Facility Mailing Address:  102 Pickering Way, Suite 105, Exton, PA 19341
Latitude/Longitude: 33.377006 N/-112.586294 W
NAICS Code: Rail- 488210; Truck- 484220/484230

The terminal facility is usually manned five days a week, Monday through Friday, 5AM-4PM PST.  Start and stop times for the shop and transload operations can vary depending on the season and business volume. During the fire season, the site could be manned up to 7 days a week. 

The entire property leased by QC West is equipped with a fence.  Reference the map in Appendix B. The gates are locked outside of active business hours.  Should a driver need access to the yard after hours, they use a code to open the gate. The facility fence line is inspected regularly to ensure function and stability. Both Union Pacific and Perimeter Solutions have access to the yard at all times, as they sublease space from QC West.  These relationships have been in place for over 15 years and there have never been any incidents that would warrant concern. QC West is currently working on installing a wir
